column4: How does one probe their usb camera to see what hardware it has / see if someone else has looked into developing a linux driver?
just plug it in, fspot should pop up if you're using gnome.
good to know. that must mean mine can't work since that's not my experience
likely the case unfortunately... although as Boohbah suggests, you can likely mount it manually as a normal USB storage device and see contents
nothing to mess with, it just tells us what the cam actually is, instead of brand names and trade mark names
that's with the cam plugged in? cuz Macrodia is generally the flash card support of most modern systems...
(ie, you can probably plug the memory card of your cam into your computer, and use it like that)
i've been at both of those links actually but thanks
gspca is in the ubuntu kernel already, so that's not your solution... but if you install 'module-assistant' you can do 'm-a a-i <module>'
ah.. i was wondereing why only source was avail
it's a command.
wouldn't have guessed that was a command, lol thanks
it is short hand for 'module-assistant auto-install'... but the creator decided (rightfully) that that's too much to type  :)
no, that tool simple compiles modules against the kernel-headers
heh, we get all sorts of questions here.

module-assistant only works if the maintainer of the module has set up helpers in the package... in the case of gspca-source, they have, however it that was going to help, the module would be loaded already.
'lsmod | grep gspca' with the cam plugged in to see whether it has.
in this case, nothing, as Ubuntu provides it compiled.
then gspca doesn't support your cam ;)

hellow: gspca is in the ubuntu kernel already, so that's not your solution... but if you install 'module-assistant' you can do 'm-a a-i <module>' that was the only reason i asked why m-a a-i would help me. i guess i was confused about the necessity of using that for gspca. meh...
see the first statement there.
